Title: The organization of the projections from the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus to orbital and medial prefrontal cortex in the monkey.
Abstract:
"The organization of interconnections between the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus (MD) and the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex and the agranular insular cortex in the monkey was studied by retrograde and anterograde tracing techniques. In addition to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions of MD, three other subdivisions can be recognized on the basis of  myeloarchitecture, cytoarchitecture, and connections. The first two of these represent a parcellation of the magnocellular division into a lateral, fiber-rich MD pars fibrosa and a medial, poorly myelinated MD pars paramediana adjacent to the midline. The third is a small, poorly myelinated area located at the caudomedial and dorsal edges of MD; it is referred to as MD
pars caudodorsalis. MD pars fibrosa is reciprocally interconnected primarily with areas 11, 12 and 13 in the central and lateral part of the orbital cortex. There is a general organization within this projection, with the rostrocaudal axis of the cortex represented from dorsal to ventral in the pars fibrosa, and the mediolateral cortical axis represented from medial to lateral. Cells that project to area 12 also extend laterally into the adjacent pars parvicellularis. MD pars paramediana is more heavily interconnected with the caudal and medial portions of the
orbital region, particularly the agranular insular areas and the caudal parts of areas 13 and 14. Cells that project to two caudal areas, 13a and Iad, do not fit with the general organization,
in that they are located in the dorsomedial parts of the pars fibrosa and pars paramediana, where they overlap with cells that project to area 14. The pars fibrosa and pars paramediana
receive inputs from areas of the ventral forebrain such as the amygdala, piriform (olfactory) cortex, and entorhinal cortex, which project directly to the orbital and agranular insular cortex, as well as from the ventral pallidum. MD pars caudodorsalis is reciprocally interconnected with areas 14, 24, and 32 on the medial surface of the prefrontal cortex. In this part of the
nucleus the dorsoventral axis of the medial prefrontal cortex is represented from caudal to rostral in the thalamus. The amygdala and other ventral forebrain structures do not send fibers into the pars caudodorsalis, even though some of these structures project directly to the medial prefrontal cortex. Ventral to MD, and separated from it by the internal medullary lamina, a small region was recognized that appears to be comparable to the anteroventral part of the submedial nucleus previously defined in the rat and cat. "
Comments: The results of the TAA-injection into "posterior piriform cortex" in case OM12 were not evaluated because it remained unclear which structures were actually affected by the injection.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52). However, some of our retrograde tracer experiments labeled cells in a distinct portion of the nucleus which was not described by Olszewski. We therefore reexamined the cytoarchitecture and myeloarchitecture of MD..."(p. 4)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Walker's ('40a) subdivisions are used for the orbital cortex, with area 11 rostrally, area 12 laterally, area 13 caudally, and area 14 medially. Serveral further subdivisions may also be recognized within these orbital areas ... The posterior orbital portion of area 12 has also been distinguished from the remainder of area 12 and is referred to as area 12o (Carmichael and Price, 94)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Area 12o of RP93 corresponds to area 12o of CP94 in location, size and name (compare Figs. 3 of RP 93 and CP94, respectively).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Walker's ('40) subdivisions are used for the orbital cortex, with area 11 rostrally, area 12 laterally, area 13 caudally, and area 14 medially. Several further subdivisions may also be recognized within these orbital areas. In particular, the medial portion of Walker's area 13 has been separated into two subdivisions, areas 13a and 13b (Amaral and Price, '84; Carmichael and Price, '94). "

"Walker's ('40) subdivisions are used for the orbital cortex, with area 11 rostrally, area 12 laterally, area 13 caudally, and area 14 medially. Several further subdivisions may also be recognized within these orbital areas. In particular, the medial portion of Walker's area 13 has been separated into two subdivisions, areas 13a and 13b (Amaral and Price, '84; Carmichael and Price, '94). "

@InterMapRelations.Comments:
MDmc and MDmg are both used to describe the pars magnocellularis of the nucleus mediodorsalis of the thalamus - however, their identity is nowhere stated explicitly.
(MDmg is used in the text and MDmc in the figures.)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52) ... " "As previous investigators have noted, two large divisions of MD can be recognized in Nissl stained sections through the rostral two-thirds of the nucleus: the pars magnocellularis and pars parvicellularis."

"Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52) ... As previous investigators have noted, two large divisions of MD can be recognized in Nissl stained sections through the rostral two-thirds of the nucleus: the pars magnocellularis and pars parvicellularis."

"In myelin stained sections, MD pars magnocellularis can be further divided, based on a plexus of fine myelinated fibers in its lateral part (Fig. 1B, D). This densely myelinated region appears to correspond to the 'nucleus medialis fibrosus' that has been described in the human MD (Hassler, '59). It will be referr not coextensive. In particular, there is a poorly myelinated region at the medial edge of MD, medial to the pars fibrosa (Fig. 1B, D). This region will be referred to as MD pars paramediana."

"Walker's ('40a) subdivisions are used for the orbital cortex, with area 11 rostrally, area 12 laterally, area 13 caudally, and area 14 medially. Several further subdivisions may also be recognized within these orbital areas ... The posterior orbital portion of area 12 has also been distinguished from the remainder of area 12 and is referred to as area 12o (Carmichael and Price, '94). Other subdivisions can also be recognized in other parts of area 12 and elsewhere in the orbital cortex (Carmichael and Price, '94), but these will not be referred to in this study."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The reference article (CP94) delineates further subdivisions of RP93-12 in Figure 3.

"Walker's ('40) subdivisions are used for the orbital cortex, with area 11 rostrally, area 12 laterally, area 13 caudally, and area 14 medially. @InterMapRelations.Citation: "The architectonic subdivisions of the prefrontal and agranular insular cortex are referred to with the same terminology used by Amaral and Price ('84), with a few modifications (Fig.3; Carmichael and Price, '94). This architectonic subdivision of the prefrontal cortex will be discussed more fully in a subsequent publication (Carmichael and Price, '94); it is similar but not identical to that used by Preuss and Goldman-Rakic ('91)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The author does not clearly state whether he uses the parcellation of AP84 or the one of CP94.

@InterMapRelations.Comments:
It is not clearly stated whether RP93-6 is - like the prefrontal areas - defined similarly to the corresponding areas in CP94. A comparison of the figures, however, indicates that RP93-6 appears to include CP94-6va, 6vb, 6d (compare Fig. 3 of RP93 with Fig. 3 of CP94).
In CP94 three subdivisions of area 6 are delineated.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52)."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: CL not being a part of the mediodorsal thalamic nucleus, it can only be assumed that other thalamic regions are also defined according to Olszweski.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52). However, some of our retrograde tracer experiments labeled cells in a distinct portion of the nucleus which was not described by Olszewski. We therefore reexamined the cytoarchitecture and myeloarchitecture of MD ... The caudal pole of MD, as described by Olszewski ('52), is occupied primarily by the pars parvicellularis. However, the medial part of this region, adjacent to the stria medullaris, can be recognized as an additional part of MD not described by Olszewski ('52). .... We will refer to this cell population according to its position in the nucleus as MD pars caudodorsalis."
@InterMapRelations.Comments: The citations above from RP93 do not clearly state (i) whether MDcd is an additional nucleus outside the MD as described by O52, or (ii) whether it is an additional subdivision that was recognized by RP93 inside the boundaries of O52-MD. A comparison of the figures from both papers (e.g. Fig. 1 in RP93 and Plates 24, 26 in O52) strongly suggest that the second option is the case.

"In myelin stained sections, MD pars magnocellularis can be further divided, based on a plexus of fine myelinated fibers in its lateral part (Fig. 1B, D). This densely myelinated region appears to correspond to the 'nucleus medialis fibrosus' that has been described in the human MD (Hassler, '59). It will be referred to as MD pars fibrosa in the following description ... " Although the position, extent and limits of MD pars fibrosa are similar to those of of MD pars magnocellularis, the two structures are not coextensive. @InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Our description of MD primarily follows the nomenclature of Olszewski ('52). However, some of our retrograde tracer experiments labeled cells in a distinct portion of the nucleus which was not described by Olszewski. We therefore reexamined the cytoarchitecture and myeloarchitecture of MD ... The caudal pole of MD, as described by Olszewski ('52), is occupied primarily by the pars parvicellularis. However, the medial part of this region, adjacent to the stria medullaris, can be recognized as an additional part of MD not described by Olszewski ('52). .... We will refer to this cell population according to its position in the nucleus as MD pars caudodorsalis."
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: The citations above from RP93 do not clearly state (i) whether MDcd is an additional nucleus outside the MD as described by O52, or (ii) whether it is an additional subdivision that was recognized by RP93 inside the boundaries of O52-MD. A comparison of the figures from both papers (e.g. Fig. 1 in RP93 and Plates 24, 26 in O52) strongly suggest that the second option is the case.

@Injections.Citation: "The thalamocortical projection to area 11, in the rostral orbital cortex, is well illustrated by case OM13, which received injections of FB and  DY into the rostral and central portions of area 11 (Fig.4), and by OM5, which received an injection of FB into the caudal part of this area."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The thalamocortical projection to area 11, in the rostral orbital cortex, is well illustrated by case OM13, which received injections of FB and  DY into the rostral and central portions of area 11 (Fig.4) ... In MD, both types of retrogradely labeled cells in OM13 are concentrated in the dorsal part of MD pars fibrosa (Fig. 6A)..."

@Injections.Citation: "OM15 received an injection of FB into area Iad (Fig.4). In this case, labeled cells are also concentrated in MD pars paramediana (Fig.9)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "OM15 received an injection of FB into area Iad (Fig.4). In this case, labeled cells are also concentrated in MD pars paramediana (Fig.9). However,  these cells are found in the dorsal part of paramedian MD, largely dorsal to the DY labeled cells in OM8. Some cells in OM15 continue dorsally into the rostral part of MD pars caudodorsalis, and in both cases there are a few labeled cells at the caudal pole of the nucleus."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Label was also found in the caudal portion of MD (" ... and in both cases there are a few labeled cells at the caudal pole of the nucleus."), however, neither text nor figure 9 clearly indicate which subdivisions of MD are affected.

@Injections.Citation: "Although this study was primarily directed towards the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex, limited observations were made on the connections of the dorsolateral (prefrontal) cortex. In particular, while it is clear from many previous studies that most of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex is connected to MD pars parvicellularis, the present experiments provide evidence for a projection from MD pars fibrosa to the cortex in the fundus of the principal sulcus (a portion of area 46).  In two cases (OM14 and OM16) in which retrograde tracers were injected into this cortical region (Fig. 4), the labeled cells in MD are limited to the dorsal part of the pars fibrosa (Fig.7A)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: " ... the labeled cells in MD are limited to the dorsal part of the pars fibrosa (Fig.7A)."

@Injections.Citation: "In another case (OM4), an injection of FB into a more rostral part of area 32, which slightly involved area 10 (Fig.4), gave rise to a very similar pattern of cell labeling throughout the anteroposterior extent of the pars caudodorsalis."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "In another case (OM4), an injection of FB into a more rostral part of area 32, which slightly involved area 10 (Fig.4), gave rise to a very similar pattern of cell labeling throughout the anteroposterior extent of the pars caudodorsalis. However, in this case more cells are labeled the posterior extreme of the nucleus."

@Injections.Citation: "The thalamocortical projection to area 11, in the rostral orbital cortex, is well illustrated by case OM13, which received injections of FB and  DY into the rostral and central portions of area 11 (Fig.4), and by OM5, which received an injection of FB into the caudal part of this area."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "The thalamocortical projection to area 11, in the rostral orbital cortex, is well illustrated by case OM13, which received injections of FB and  DY into the rostral and central portions of area 11 (Fig.4), and by OM5, which received an injection of FB into the caudal part of this area ... the labeled cells ... in OM5 are located more ventrally, in the central part of the pars fibrosa (Fig.6B). Most of these cells are found in the rostral three quarters of MD, although there are a few at the caudal pole of the nucleus."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Label was also found in the rostral and caudal portions of MD (see citation above), however, neither text nor Figure 6B clearly indicate which subdivisions of MD are affected.

@Injections.Citation: "After an injection of FB into area 14 (OM6; Fig.4), the labeled cells are concentrated in the dorsal part of MD pars paramediana and the adjacent rostral part of the pars caudodorsalis (Fig.13)."
@Injections.Comments: The text does not state that the injection in case OM6 affects any other site than area 14, whereas Figure 4 gives the impression that a narrow strip of area 10 may also affected by the injection.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "After an injection of FB into area 14 (OM6; Fig.4), the labeled cells are concentrated in the dorsal part of MD pars paramediana and the adjacent rostral part of the pars caudodorsalis (Fig.13)."

@Injections.Citation: "In a third case (OM8), an injection of FB limited to area 13b labeled cells in the ventral half of pars fibrosa and pars paramediana (Fig.7B), in a similar pattern to that seen in OM5."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Cases OM14 and OM9 received injections into rostral area 12; the injection in OM14 slightly involved area 46, while the injection in OM9 was slightly more caudolateral and avoided area 46 (Fig.4). The extension of cells into pars parvicellularis is not due to involvment of area 46 since it is more prominent in OM9 in which area 46 was not involved [by the injection]."

@Injections.Citation: "However area 13a in the caudomedial corner of the orbital cortex appears to be a special case, which does not fit this general organization of thalamocortical projections to the orbital cortex. @LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "An injection of 3H-leucine into area 32 in OM13 (Fig. 4) labeled axons in MD pars caudodorsalis throughout its anteroposterior extent, with only minimal label in MD pars parvicellularis, and none in pars fibrosa (Fig. 6A). @LabelledSites_Data.Comments: Fig. 16 shows some labeled neurons within MDfi.

@Injections.Citation: "Case OM14 received an injection of 3H-leucine that was centered in the lateral half of MD pars fibrosa and avoided the pars parvicellularis, pars caudodorsalis and pars paramediana (Fig. 10)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Case OM14 received an injection of 3H-leucine that was centered in the lateral half of MD pars fibrosa and avoided the pars parvicellularis, pars caudodorsalis and pars paramediana (Fig. 10). There is dense anterograde label in the orbital cortex (areas 11,12 and 13), and in the depths of the principal sulcus (area 46; Figs.10 and 11). Less dense label is found in area 13b and the agranular insular fields ... and in areas 9, 45 ... Label is conspicuously absent in areas 14, 25 and 32 ... And only traces of label were found in areas 10 and 24."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:
Information on labeling density is displayed in Figure 10 by means of three different hatches wich presumably represent weak, moderate, and strong degrees of labeling. This relation, however, is not stated explicitly, but can only be inferred from the text.
If the particular area shows more than one hatch in Figure 10 and there was no textual information avaliable we assigned the highest degree of labeling as indicated by the hatches.

@Injections.Citation: "Although this study was primarily directed towards the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex, limited observations were made on the connections of the dorsolateral (prefrontal) cortex. In two cases (OM14 and OM16) in which retrograde tracers were injected into this cortical region (Fig. 4), the labeled cells in MD are limited to the dorsal part of the pars fibrosa (Fig.7A)."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments:

publication.title: The organization of the projections from the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus to orbital and medial prefrontal cortex in the monkey.
publication.abstract:
"The organization of interconnections between the mediodorsal nucleus of the thalamus (MD) and the orbital and medial prefrontal cortex and the agranular insular cortex in the monkey was studied by retrograde and anterograde tracing techniques. In addition to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions of MD, three other subdivisions can be recognized on the basis of  myeloarchitecture, cytoarchitecture, and connections. The first two of these represent a parcellation of the magnocellular division into a lateral, fiber-rich MD pars fibrosa and a medial, poorly myelinated MD pars paramediana adjacent to the midline. The third is a small, poorly myelinated area located at the caudomedial and dorsal edges of MD; it is referred to as MD
pars caudodorsalis. MD pars fibrosa is reciprocally interconnected primarily with areas 11, 12 and 13 in the central and lateral part of the orbital cortex. There is a general organization within this projection, with the rostrocaudal axis of the cortex represented from dorsal to ventral in the pars fibrosa, and the mediolateral cortical axis represented from medial to lateral. Cells that project to area 12 also extend laterally into the adjacent pars parvicellularis. MD pars paramediana is more heavily interconnected with the caudal and medial portions of the
orbital region, particularly the agranular insular areas and the caudal parts of areas 13 and 14. Cells that project to two caudal areas, 13a and Iad, do not fit with the general organization,
in that they are located in the dorsomedial parts of the pars fibrosa and pars paramediana, where they overlap with cells that project to area 14. The pars fibrosa and pars paramediana
receive inputs from areas of the ventral forebrain such as the amygdala, piriform (olfactory) cortex, and entorhinal cortex, which project directly to the orbital and agranular insular cortex, as well as from the ventral pallidum. MD pars caudodorsalis is reciprocally interconnected with areas 14, 24, and 32 on the medial surface of the prefrontal cortex. In this part of the
nucleus the dorsoventral axis of the medial prefrontal cortex is represented from caudal to rostral in the thalamus. The amygdala and other ventral forebrain structures do not send fibers into the pars caudodorsalis, even though some of these structures project directly to the medial prefrontal cortex. Ventral to MD, and separated from it by the internal medullary lamina, a small region was recognized that appears to be comparable to the anteroventral part of the submedial nucleus previously defined in the rat and cat. "
